channel.title: Life Matters - Full program podcast
channel.itunes:subtitle: Life Matters podcast gives you the complete program from start to finish, with Natasha Mitchell hosting interviews and discussions about what's affecting our daily health and wellbeing at home, work and school.
channel.description: Life Matters podcast gives you the complete program from start to finish, with Natasha Mitchell hosting interviews and discussions about what's affecting our daily health and wellbeing at home, work and school.

item.itunes:subtitle: The Mind-Up program:  looking at the connection between our thoughts and our emotions; Rebecca Huntley and her family’s history; This rental life part 1 – the portable oasis.

item.itunes:subtitle: How does alcohol affect us? Our health and our relationships?; we get in the back of a few different ambulances for the Sydney Film Festival; cricket in retirement; and we hear a grandmother’s tale.

item.title: Thursday 31 May 2012
item.itunes:subtitle: The free-range egg debate: why consumers seem to care; Round Midnight – Nica Rothschild’s love for jazz great, Thelonious Monk and the 21 day challenge to raise money for homeless youth.

item.title: Tuesday 29 May 2012
item.itunes:subtitle: GP after-hours services: who uses them and what’s their future? How has Australia responded to the UN’s concerns over our country’s child rights? And we meet our Life Matters listener this week: fly-in fly-out nurse Jan Philips who has worked in some of the most isolated places in Australia.
item.description: GP after-hours services: who uses them and what’s their future? How has Australia responded to the UN’s concerns over our country’s child rights? And we meet our Life Matters listener this week: fly-in fly-out nurse Jan Philips who has worked in some of the most isolated places in Australia.
item.itunes:author: Natasha Mitchell

item.title: Monday 28 May 2012
item.itunes:subtitle: Breasts - living a life they’ve never lived before; casualties of the mining boom and modern dilemmas - how much do you tell the kids post divorce?

item.title: Thursday 24 May 2012
item.itunes:subtitle: Dying at home surrounded by the people who love you is often seen to be preferable to a hospital death but sometimes you need to fight for the right to die where you choose. Also neuropsychonalysis, it’s all about our dreams. Plus the longevity of the suit and tie – why is it so enduring?
item.description: Dying at home surrounded by the people who love you is often seen to be preferable to a hospital death but sometimes you need to fight for the right to die where you choose. Also neuropsychonalysis, it’s all about our dreams. Plus the longevity of the suit and tie – why is it so enduring?
item.itunes:author: Natasha Mitchell

item.title: Wednesday 23 May 2012
item.itunes:subtitle: Meet Mitchell Dahlstrom, he's one of 50 young people taking part in the first Indigenous Youth Parliament in Canberra this week. Tackling the vexed issue of workplace bullying. And an innovative approach to connecting kids around the globe, plus your letters and calls.
item.description: Meet Mitchell Dahlstrom, he's one of 50 young people taking part in the first Indigenous Youth Parliament in Canberra this week. Tackling the vexed issue of workplace bullying. And an innovative approach to connecting kids around the globe, plus your letters and calls.

item.title: Tuesday 22 May 2012
item.itunes:subtitle: Access to abortion in Australia: what are the costs?; Is it time to introduce EEO targets and quotas for women in the workplace?; We head to The Track as part of the RN series On Location; and meet Life Matters listener, Michelle “Mamabake” Shearer.
item.description: Access to abortion in Australia: what are the costs?; Is it time to introduce EEO targets and quotas for women in the workplace?; We head to The Track as part of the RN series On Location; and meet Life Matters listener, Michelle “Mamabake” Shearer.
item.itunes:author: Natasha Mitchell

item.title: Monday 21 May 2012
item.itunes:subtitle: Barbara Arrowsmith-Young was born with a major learning disability, but she was determined to try and overcome this and in so doing, she pushed against orthodoxies in science and in education. Over the years she has transformed her own life and she has helped change the lives of countless others. She says that: 'By changing the brain, we can change how we learn'. This makes sense to us today, but when Barbara started experimenting with her own brain, the idea that we can manipulate the physiology of our brains through excercising it, pushed against the orthodoxy of the time.
item.description: Barbara Arrowsmith-Young was born with a major learning disability, but she was determined to try and overcome this and in so doing, she pushed against orthodoxies in science and in education. Over the years she has transformed her own life and she has helped change the lives of countless others. She says that: 'By changing the brain, we can change how we learn'. This makes sense to us today, but when Barbara started experimenting with her own brain, the idea that we can manipulate the physiology of our brains through excercising it, pushed against the orthodoxy of the time.
item.itunes:author: Natasha Mitchell

item.itunes:subtitle: Can we prevent torture? An ex CIA interrogator believes so; the Australian colony in Paraguay – still going strong after 120 years and human rights photographer, Jagath Dheerasekara.

item.itunes:subtitle: Pastoral care for the FIFO workers around the country, and the fascinating life of beat poet Lemon Andersen. Plus we meet Beverley Bergen a former broadcaster and opera singer whose favourite place is on the ski slopes - complete with her newly reconstructed knee.

item.title: Wednesday 02 May 2012
item.itunes:subtitle: Do employers need an incentive to recruit over 50's into their workforce? How a 'fit note' can be better than a sick note. And why does our mobile phone usage come with some evolutionary baggage. Plus your feedback.
item.description: Do employers need an incentive to recruit over 50's into their workforce? How a 'fit note' can be better than a sick note. And why does our mobile phone usage come with some evolutionary baggage. Plus your feedback.

item.title: Friday 27th April 2012
item.itunes:subtitle: What are the days or moments that have affected your life? A new website created as part of the ABCs 80th birthday in July has drawn on the vast bounty that is ABC archives to bring you '80 days that changed our lives'.
item.description: What are the days or moments that have affected your life? A new website created as part of the ABCs 80th birthday in July has drawn on the vast bounty that is ABC archives to bring you '80 days that changed our lives'.

item.title: Thursday 26 April 2012
item.itunes:subtitle: Can post-traumatic stress be a powerful experience for growth? We also talk about the “forgotten sister” of Pride & Prejudice ... We look back at the 80 days that changed our lives ... and we hear the tale of a sailor and an astronaut
item.description: Can post-traumatic stress be a powerful experience for growth? We also talk about the “forgotten sister” of Pride & Prejudice ... We look back at the 80 days that changed our lives ... and we hear the tale of a sailor and an astronaut

item.itunes:subtitle: We remember the experiences of World War 1 nurses, frontline soldiers and those who visit Gallipoli to commemorate the iconic battle.

item.title: Tuesday 24 April 2012
item.itunes:subtitle: Skilling up the carers in aged care; dads with depression; meningitis - on World Meningitis Day what’s the latest research on treatment? And we meet a listener who enjoys his solitude - at one time in his life his nearest neighbour was a space station.
item.description: Skilling up the carers in aged care; dads with depression; meningitis - on World Meningitis Day what’s the latest research on treatment? And we meet a listener who enjoys his solitude - at one time in his life his nearest neighbour was a space station.

item.title: Friday Talkback: Solitude

item.itunes:subtitle: The Afar women of Ethiopia. Too many celebrants. Fair or not: Fair Work Act.

item.itunes:author: Natasha Mitchell

item.title: Wednesday 18 April 2012
item.itunes:subtitle: The promise of microbicides in the treatment of HIV. Plus a couple of creative pursuits - how performance anxiety might be a good thing, and how children can learn critical thinking through art.
item.description: The promise of microbicides in the treatment of HIV. Plus a couple of creative pursuits - how performance anxiety might be a good thing, and how children can learn critical thinking through art.

item.title: Tuesday 17 April 2012
item.itunes:subtitle: How important are the early years of a child’s life for success at school and life? We’ll also be talking about renewables – what do we really think of them? We walk through the shelves of the famous Reader’s Feast bookstore; and we’ll find out just how one pair of grandparents came to the rescue.
item.description: How important are the early years of a child’s life for success at school and life? We’ll also be talking about renewables – what do we really think of them? We walk through the shelves of the famous Reader’s Feast bookstore; and we’ll find out just how one pair of grandparents came to the rescue.
item.itunes:author: Natasha Mitchell

item.title: Monday 16 April 2012
item.itunes:subtitle: Visiting American farmer Michael Ableman talks urban agriculture. A challenging interview with a couples counsellor on her novel exploring intimate violence at home. Plus a dilemma, whether to return a highly valuable donation to its rightful owner, or stash the cash for charity.
item.description: Visiting American farmer Michael Ableman talks urban agriculture. A challenging interview with a couples counsellor on her novel exploring intimate violence at home. Plus a dilemma, whether to return a highly valuable donation to its rightful owner, or stash the cash for charity.
item.itunes:author: Natasha Mitchell

item.title: Thursday 12 April 2012
item.itunes:subtitle: How will the National Disability Insurance Scheme work and what does it mean for those who need it most? Micro-labour ... a new era of bidding for work online. And we look at what’s being called a positive new approach to raising happy teen girls.
item.description: How will the National Disability Insurance Scheme work and what does it mean for those who need it most? Micro-labour ... a new era of bidding for work online. And we look at what’s being called a positive new approach to raising happy teen girls.
item.itunes:author: Wendy Harmer

item.title: Tuesday 10 April 2012
item.itunes:subtitle: Kids and the flu vaccine; a former Neighbours star who, after he broke his real-life neighbour’s nose realised he needed to confront his anger management problem; a business started 45 years ago was really ahead of its time and we speak to its founder, Dena Blackman and a listener who can’t get enough of life in the desert – both here and overseas.
item.description: Kids and the flu vaccine; a former Neighbours star who, after he broke his real-life neighbour’s nose realised he needed to confront his anger management problem; a business started 45 years ago was really ahead of its time and we speak to its founder, Dena Blackman and a listener who can’t get enough of life in the desert – both here and overseas.
item.itunes:author: Wendy Harmer

item.title: Monday 9th April 2012
item.itunes:subtitle: Simon Winchester on his book Atlantic: A vast ocean of a million stories and a book club in Darwin celebrates its 20th year.
item.description: Simon Winchester on his book Atlantic: A vast ocean of a million stories and a book club in Darwin celebrates its 20th year.
item.itunes:author: Natasha Mitchell

item.title: Friday 6th April 2012
item.itunes:subtitle: The future of Australian cities and writer Kaz Cooke
item.description: The future of Australian cities and writer Kaz Cooke
item.itunes:author: Natasha Mitchell

item.title: Thursday 05 April 2012
item.itunes:subtitle: The homework debate; drug users respond to our recent interview on the ethics of cash incentives for drug addicts to take long acting contraception; and our fashion writing in cyberspace.
item.description: The homework debate; drug users respond to our recent interview on the ethics of cash incentives for drug addicts to take long acting contraception; and our fashion writing in cyberspace.
item.itunes:author: Natasha Mitchell

item.title: Wednesday 04 April 2012
item.itunes:subtitle: Francesca Martinez: the wobbly girl. Co-sleeping with your child: do you do it? Trapeze artists, Chloe and James Holt. Your feedback.
item.description: Francesca Martinez: the wobbly girl. Co-sleeping with your child: do you do it? Trapeze artists, Chloe and James Holt. Your feedback.
item.itunes:author: Natasha Mitchell

item.title: Tuesday 3 April 2012
item.itunes:subtitle: As the debate continues over the merits of extending childcare subsidies to cover the costs of nannies, one Australian woman says we need to be taking a bigger view. Plus comedian Shappi Khorsandi, the daughter of Iranian refugees will be performing at the Melbourne Comedy Festival. Plus how four bikes and one tent can make for a ripping adventure.
item.description: As the debate continues over the merits of extending childcare subsidies to cover the costs of nannies, one Australian woman says we need to be taking a bigger view. Plus comedian Shappi Khorsandi, the daughter of Iranian refugees will be performing at the Melbourne Comedy Festival. Plus how four bikes and one tent can make for a ripping adventure.
item.itunes:author: Natasha Mitchell

item.title: Monday 02 April 2012
item.itunes:subtitle: A targeted way to treat problem gamblers: is it effective? Ben Robertson: stay at home dad; And modern dilemmas: what can you do when your boss is a liar?
item.description: A targeted way to treat problem gamblers: is it effective? Ben Robertson: stay at home dad; And modern dilemmas: what can you do when your boss is a liar?
item.itunes:author: Natasha Mitchell

item.title: Friday 30 March 2012
item.itunes:subtitle: Grandparents—they’re the custodians of family wisdom—living ancestors who communicate the history of the family and nurture their charges. But what’s it like to be a grandparent today? Australians are working longer and having babies later so what impact does this have on the role of grandparents? Of course it’s not always all beer and skittles—maybe you’re a grandparent who’s struggling to juggle the competing priorities of work, caring for your own parents, meeting your own child’s requests for child care and trying to find a moment for yourself to boot.
item.description: Grandparents—they’re the custodians of family wisdom—living ancestors who communicate the history of the family and nurture their charges. But what’s it like to be a grandparent today? Australians are working longer and having babies later so what impact does this have on the role of grandparents? Of course it’s not always all beer and skittles—maybe you’re a grandparent who’s struggling to juggle the competing priorities of work, caring for your own parents, meeting your own child’s requests for child care and trying to find a moment for yourself to boot.
item.itunes:author: Natasha Mitchell

item.title: Thursday 29 March 2012
item.itunes:subtitle: Confronting research on some of the disturbing sexism found in lads mags, sex ed by stealth. Personalised medicine and how genomics might change our next trip to the doctor . Plus a question of human liberty or protecting the innocent, is it morally acceptable to offer financial reward to addicted men and women who agree to sterilization or long term contraception.
item.description: Confronting research on some of the disturbing sexism found in lads mags, sex ed by stealth. Personalised medicine and how genomics might change our next trip to the doctor . Plus a question of human liberty or protecting the innocent, is it morally acceptable to offer financial reward to addicted men and women who agree to sterilization or long term contraception.
item.itunes:author: Natasha Mitchell

item.title: Wednesday 28 March 2012
item.itunes:subtitle: Young leaders encouraging more youth to be active in the social services sector, and talking of social – did you know it was impossible for some people with disabilities to access sites like Twitter – why and how is it getting fixed? And how would you react if your 7 year old son told you he was gay?
item.description: Young leaders encouraging more youth to be active in the social services sector, and talking of social – did you know it was impossible for some people with disabilities to access sites like Twitter – why and how is it getting fixed? And how would you react if your 7 year old son told you he was gay?
item.itunes:author: Natasha Mitchell

item.title: Tuesday 27 March 2012
item.itunes:subtitle: A new report on the sex industry in New South Wales says that decriminalization has produced good occupational health and welfare standards and cautions against alternative regulation, Legendary British comic and agitator, Mark Thomas talks about his attempt to walk the entire length of the Israeli barrier in the West Bank and we meet a listener who is having a love affair with the Ukelele.
item.description: A new report on the sex industry in New South Wales says that decriminalization has produced good occupational health and welfare standards and cautions against alternative regulation, Legendary British comic and agitator, Mark Thomas talks about his attempt to walk the entire length of the Israeli barrier in the West Bank and we meet a listener who is having a love affair with the Ukelele.
item.itunes:author: Natasha Mitchell

item.title: Monday 26th March 2012
item.itunes:subtitle: Fertility - new research suggests many men and women still don’t understand the specifics of declining fertility; Ottmar Edenhofer, the head of the Potsdam Institute for Climate Impact Research, and Modern Dilemma: What to do when the adult kids won’t pay their way?
item.description: Fertility - new research suggests many men and women still don’t understand the specifics of declining fertility; Ottmar Edenhofer, the head of the Potsdam Institute for Climate Impact Research, and Modern Dilemma: What to do when the adult kids won’t pay their way?
item.itunes:author: Natasha Mitchell

item.title: Friday 23 March 2012
item.itunes:subtitle: Talkback all about computer games. Hear why people love them, or hate them.
item.description: Talkback all about computer games. Hear why people love them, or hate them.
item.itunes:author: Natasha Mitchell
